items.title: LargeZipFile exception for huge file creation
items.body:
Creation of huge files (excel file size 135MB) causes a LargeZipFile exception for me: 
LargeZipFile: Filesize would require ZIP64 extensions

I could solve that by adding allowZip64=True parameter to following line:

https://github.com/kz26/PyExcelerate/blob/d39b05307bbc80c83b4140822305bf8976396d97/pyexcelerate/Writer.py#L45

Is it possible to set an attribute/add a parameter somewhere (e.g. Workbook, Workbook.save ) to allow 64-bit usage (maybe in a future release)?

items.title: Expose a way to save using a filehandler

items.title: Hyper Link is not working
items.body:
When I am Using hyperlink formula as below:

sheet.set_cell_value(3, 3, '=HYPERLINK("https://abc.com/download", "Download File")')

In the excel file showing formula is invalid because It's adding 1 more (=) equal, Formula in excel sheet as below:

==HYPERLINK("https://abc.com/download", "Download File")
means It's adding additional (=) equals. When I am using formula without (=) equal 

sheet.set_cell_value(3, 3, 'HYPERLINK("https://abc.com/download", "Download File")')

In the excel file showing formula is invalid.

HYPERLINK("https://abc.com/download", "Download File")

The valid link should be as below:
=HYPERLINK("https://abc.com/download", "Download File")

Please check and fix it.

items.title: Formula not working
items.body:
I'm trying to use HYPERLINK formula as follows - 

`ws.set_cell_value(1, 1, '=HYPERLINK("www.someurl.com", "Click here")')
`

But when I look at the underlying cell(1, 1) in excel file, it complains that formula is invalid. Actually pyexcelerate prepends an additional `=` sign, so above formula is translated to - 

> ==HYPERLINK("www.someurl.com", "Click here")

I also tried to use the formula without `=` sign as follows -

`ws.set_cell_value(1, 1, 'HYPERLINK("www.someurl.com", "Click here")')
`

So in this is case excel client complains that that formula is invalid, it's because there is no `=` sign, so above formula is translated to - 

> HYPERLINK("www.someurl.com", "Click here")

valid formula must contain only one `=` sign in the cell, e.g. 
> =HYPERLINK("www.someurl.com", "Click here")     #This is valid

items.title: MemoryError while generating large Excel file
items.body:
Hey, First of all, thanks for this awesome projects. It's people like you that keep this wave going.

I am trying to profile `PyExcelerate` by creating an Excel file with 500k rows and 50 cols but suddenly it threw me a MemoryError:-

**My Code :-**
```py
def evaluate_pyexcelerate(target):
    two_d_list = []
    headers = []
    for i in range(50):
        headers.append("Col {0}".format(i))
    two_d_list.append(headers)
    wb = pyexcelerate.Workbook()
    for row in range(500000):
        values = []
        for index, _  in enumerate(headers):
            values.append("Col + Row {0}".format(index + row + 2))
        two_d_list.append(values)
    ws = wb.new_sheet("sheet 1", data=two_d_list)
    wb.save(target)

start_time_pyexcelerate = time.time()
evaluate_pyexcelerate("pyexcelerate_a1_500k.xlsx")
print("%s seconds on PyExcelerate" % (time.time() - start_time_pyexcelerate))
```
**Error Traceaback :-**
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "c:/Users/Tarun_19/Desktop/script.py", line 21, in <module>
    evaluate_pyexcelerate("pyexcelerate_a1_500k.xlsx")
  File "c:/Users/Tarun_19/Desktop/script.py", line 17, in evaluate_pyexcelerate
    ws = wb.new_sheet("sheet 1", data=two_d_list)
  File "c:\python27\lib\site-packages\pyexcelerate\Workbook.py", line 24, in new_sheet
    worksheet = Worksheet.Worksheet(sheet_name, self, data, force_name)
  File "c:\python27\lib\site-packages\pyexcelerate\Worksheet.py", line 33, in __init__
    self._cells[x][y] = cell
MemoryError
```
Also, it is worth mentioning that i did the same thing some time back and it worked perfectly.

items.title: `import __version__` in `setup.py` breaks dependency processing
items.body:
Hello,

Beginning with 0.7.0, I cannot install PyExcelerate in a fresh virtualenv without manually installing `six` or `Jinja2` first. I believe that `from pyexcelerate.version import __version__` in `setup.py` fails unless these dependencies are already installed, and therefore `pip` cannot process the package at all.

```
$ virtualenv /tmp/e
New python executable in /tmp/e/bin/python
Installing setuptools, pip...done.
$ . /tmp/e/bin/activate
(e)$ pip install --upgrade pip

Installing collected packages: pip
  Found existing installation: pip 1.5.4

Successfully installed pip
Cleaning up...
(e)$ pip install PyExcelerate
Collecting PyExcelerate
  Using cached PyExcelerate-0.7.0.tar.gz

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>

        from pyexcelerate.version import __version__
      File "pyexcelerate/__init__.py", line 1, in <module>

      File "pyexcelerate/Workbook.py", line 1, in <module>
```

items.title: Zeros are deleted when styles are set
Autofit broken
Range limited to 65536 rows * 256 columns
items.body:
In pyexcelerate/Range.py, there is a check to throw a "Row/Column index out of bounds" exception when row is over 65536 or column over 256.
So, when styling a range such as ws.range((2,2),(2,400000)).style.format = Format('dd/mm/yyyy'), it throws the exception.

If I'm not mistaken, those are old limitations from the 97/2000 xls format. The xlsx format supports up to 1048576 rows \* 16384 columns.
I updated the values, and was able to style this big table.

items.title: Max rows = 65536
items.body:
There appears to be a hard limit on how many rows Range.Range can reference. From line 17 of file Range.py:

```
if (not (1 <= self._start[0] <= 65536) and self._start[0] != float('inf')) \
    or (not (1 <= self._end[0] <= 65536) and self._end[0] != float('inf')):
    raise Exception("Row index out of bounds")
if (not (1 <= self._start[1] <= 256) and self._start[1] != float('inf')) \
    or (not (1 <= self._end[1] <= 256) and self._end[1] != float('inf')):
    raise Exception("Column index out of bounds")
```

Any reason behind this? Populating the worksheet with rows exceeding that limit works fine. The issue applies only to this class.

If for some reason there needs to be a limit, it should be whatever the spec for xlsx files is (1,048,576).

items.title: Setup.py not compatible with Python 3

python setup.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):

NameError: name 'execfile' is not defined

Any chance of a setup.py that has a `develop` option?

items.title: decimal.Decimal not included in DataTypes._numberTypes
items.body:
In version 0.5.0 I'm getting KeyError exceptions in Worksheet.py on line 143 for any cell with a decimal.Decimal value.

I tracked the error back to line 21 of DataTypes.py. Because Decimal values aren't being identified as DataTypes.NUMBER or any other type, they are never added to cell_cache. Thus the exceptions.

Importing the decimal module and changing line 21 of DataTypes.py to

```
_numberTypes = six.integer_types + (float, complex, decimal.Decimal)
```

fixes the problem.

items.title: Add column autowidth support
items.body:
Hi,

Generating an Excel file with column having all the same width, even with data too large for the width, doesn't look "professional".

I was using Simplistix xlwt python 2.x library, and I'm switching to PyExcelerate and python 3.x, up to now it's the only feature I'm missing.

Sébastien

items.title: Add border support and support for applying default Excel styles
items.body: Borders and default styles with an enum :D

items.title: Dates and times require a number format to render correctly in Excel
items.body:
Hi,

Currently PyExcelerate writes dates using the Excel `d` (ISO 8601 date) attribute of the `c` (cell) element of the `worksheet.xml` file. While this is valid under section 18.18.11 ST_CellType (Cell Type) of [ECMA-376](http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/standards/Ecma-376.htm) there are a couple of issue with it.

The first is that although it is valid under the above specification it is unusual in practice. Excel 2007 doesn't support it and later Excel's read it but don't write it.\* Also, modules such as `xlrd` don't read it.

For greater compatibility with other modules/applications it would be better to convert the date/time to a serial number and store that instead. However, since it isn't strictly a bug that decision is up to you.

The second issue is that in either ISO 8601 or number format the date should have a number format attached to it via the cell `s` (style) attribute so that it renders as a date/time. Currently dates in files created by PyExcelerate render as decimal numbers. For example, here is the output from the date example in the Readme:

![screenshot](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/94267/1277099/3e876962-2eab-11e3-869b-32905b6e4f49.png)

Ideally, to fix this PyExcelerate should include a styles.xml file with one or more default formats for dates and times and references them when writing dates/times.

(*) It may be supported in Excel 2013.

items.title: Floating point numbers lose precision when written
items.body:
Hi,

Excel supports IEEE 754 64 bit floats with around 15 digits of precision.

However, PyExcelerate writes floating point numbers with `%f` precision which is around 8 digits of precision.

As a result precision is lost when re-reading an xlsx file written with PyExcelerate

John

items.title: All floats convert to int
items.body: Between 0.2.3 and 0.2.4, something happened and numbers are now converted to ints when I desire floats in my workbook. Only tested with range().value= method of inserting data so far.

items.title: Add style support
items.body: Add support for styles in cells, like bolding and stuff.

items.title: Range writer acts oddly with numpy arrays.
items.body:
Something is off with how rectangular arrays are handled. For example:
`numpy.zeros((13,196))` has 13 rows, and 196 columns - a long rectangle.

One /should/ pass it as `range('A1', 'GN13')`, but this fails. But the following does work:
`DC_sheet.range('A1', 'M196').value = numpy.zeros((13,196))`
which, appears to be a tall excel rectangle of similar dimension. However, the resulting sheet actually spans from
A1 to GN13 - correctly a long rectangle.

items.title: Program doesn't like Numpy Arrays
items.body:
I wanted to try the benchmark script with a Numpy array, and found that the program simply writes an empty .xlsx file, rather than a proper sheet of ones. The script does not throw any error as it fails to deliver the desired result. Below is the script I used.

```
import time, pyexcelerate, numpy

ROWS = 65000
COLUMNS = 100
wb = pyexcelerate.Workbook()
testData = numpy.ones((ROWS, COLUMNS), dtype = int)
stime = time.clock()
ws = wb.new_sheet("Test 1", data=testData)
wb.save("test.xlsx")
print "pyexcelerate, %s, %s, %s" % (ROWS, COLUMNS, time.clock() - stime)
```
